Discussion group
resumes meetings

After an absence of some months
from student affairs, the Campus Discussion group will hoia its first meeting of the year this afternoon in
Levering hall.
In the past the organization has
devoted the majority of its time to
pertinent social and religious topics
of the day, and this program is to be
continued doring the remainder of this
year.
An attractive feature of the Discussion Group is that the membership is made up of faculty and students alike, enabling a closer feeling
of cooperation to exist between the
two.
The chairman of the club is Morris
Wessel, while the remaining officers
will be selected at the meeting Friday. At present, plans are being arranged for forming a committee of
students and faculty to formulate
plans for the year's program.

Over eight hundred return to a
hum-drum - - what a conundrum
By KENNETH MAXCY JR
The intensive "back-to-class"
movement sponsored by the NEWSLETTER yesterday and today has succeeded in returning over eight hundred students to their classes, according to a flash from the registrar.
The promising results have led the
NEWS-LETTER to consider a campuswide poll on—College, yes? or no?
Comments on the exams show
unfavorable
universal
practically
sentiment on the lack of imagination
in exam questions. Disapproving students even went so far as to greet
some examinations with stamping
feet and cat-calls.
"These questions have less personality than the questions in a teacher's text supplement," one student
was overheard to say. Such a scathing indictment reflects to a large extent upon the faculty.
The official notice that "ignorance
is no excuse" also received pointed
criticism.
Compliments were received by the
administration, however, on the firstaid stations and refreshment stands
installed betwen examination rooms.
This rebuked the Student council
which had objected to them as
against the "democratic" school
spirit of "rugged individualism."
The mysterious sudden appearance
of swarms of butterflies in the History B examination room is still unexplained. Conjectures relating it to
the high price of spinach have been
generally discredited by a subsequent
fall in the price of spinach and the

continued appearance of the swarms
of butterflies.
And now that we can pick up the
poker hands where we left off and
finish off that stein of malt, we have
started looking around for a shady
spot to sit and watch the spring grass
grow until finals.
So, in a reasonably accurate facsimile of words by the imortal 0'
Henry let us conclude. "Oh! heap our
plates with golden fruit and let us
twine round our brows wreathes of
poison ivy, for the season of irresponsibility is at hand."

Dr Thomas Parran
Dr Parran has devoted the greater
portion of his life to serving the
public. After his graduation from the
Georgetown University medical
school in 1915, and serving as an
interne at Sibley Memorial Hospital
in Washington, he obtained a temporary appointment in 1916 to do rural
Health Service Commission. The following year he was commissioned an
sanitation work for the US Public
officer in the regular corps, and after
serving in fourteen states on various
public health projects for fourteen
years, he was appointed in 1930 as
Commissioner of Health for New
York State.

Pi D E to initiate
ten new members
February 10
Nine men will be tapped next week
by Pi Delta Epsilon, the national
honorary journalism fraternity, according to Seymour Sacks, secretarytreasurer of the Hopkins chapter.
They are Allan Hecht, Bill Bradley,
Leonard Quitt, Charles Diggs, John
Levy, Bob Hoopes, Buddy Macht,
Buster Rosette, and William Freedman.
Dr Gerald W Johnson, outstanding
editorialist of the Baltimore Evening
Sun and contributor to many national magazines has accepted a bid
for honorary membership and will be
guest of honor at an initiation banquet to be held in the clubrooms of
the Blackstone Apartments next Friday evening.
Members are taken into PDE on
the basis of having done outstanding work in campus journalism and
general ability.
Although the primary purpose of
the fraternity is to promote improved
and uncensored campus publications,
Wethered Barroll, jr, president of the
local chapter of Pi D E has appointed

Band adopts ROTC
rank system
"In an effort to build up spirit in
the band in the hope of adding spirit
to the campus, the band has instigated a system of rank copied after
that used in the regular ROTC units.
The band, mainly a school and not
an ROTC function, has not, in the
past, been very well coordinated.
There was a definite lack of incentive,
the varsity seal being the only reward for membership, and attendance
at games and drills was very poor.
The creation of three sergeants
was the first step to increase band
spirit and a set of awards is being
worked out in this connection.
The three sergeants appointed are
Bill Wetzler, George Elliot, and
Francis Diehl.
Since these appointments few
weeks ago, there has been a definite
improvement in band spirit and
morale as represented by better drill
attendance and increased cooperation.
It is hoped that this improvement
will be continued in order that the
organization be able to gain the recognition it should receive on the
campus. The structure and material
are present to give Hopkins a real
band, and under these new adjustments, this hope may be realized.

Liberal club
meets officially
next Friday
The first official meeting of the
Liberal Club will be held next Friday
at 1:00 in Levering hall, it was decided

at an organization meeting
yesterday. Two members of the faculty will speak on the purpose of the
club and their interpretation of a
liberal. The meeting will be an open
one, with the entire student body invited. Murray Kempton will outline
for newcomers the proposed structure
and functions of the group.
Leaders of the club expect to complete organizational work before the
coming meeting. Next Thursday at
lunch time the club organizers will
meet in the NEWS-LETTER office to delimit the fields covered by each of
the club's four committees, the Social problems committee, the Labor
Problems committee, the Peace committee, and the Campus committee.
Since interest in the Social problems committee has so far detracted
from interest in the Labor problems committee has se far detracted
social security and wages and hours
have been shifted
the foi-mer
to the latter. If present plans mature
the Campus committee will undertake as one of its activities a poll on
campus opinion on various issues.
Before next Friday the club nucleus
also intends to re-word the preamble
to its constitution so as to give it
unity of purpose and yet keep it sufficiently eclectic. Copies of the preamble as reviewed by Murray Kempton will be distributed to prospective
members for criticism. Members have
questioned most the phrases dedicating the group to "economic democracy". An attempt will be made to
find out how the term ought best to
be defined.

Dr Stephens returns
The NEWS-LETTER wishes to take
this opportunity to welcome bailt
Dr Stephens of the Psychology department, who has been ill for the
past few weeks.
Dr Stephens was stricken a few
days before the Christmas holidays
began and did not return to the University until several days ago.

A last minute notice from Tommy
Dorsey refusing an offer by the
Board of Social Activities this week,
sent the committee scurrying again
for a name band with a great Baltimore following, and upset all planned
arrangements for the affair scheduled for February 9, at the Alcazar.
With only a few more days until
the affair, the disappointing result
after more than three hundred pledges
had been signed by the student body
caused an important meeting between Harold Ricards, president of
the Student council and the BSA
this afternoon.
The closed meeting will consider
plans for signing Jimmy Dorsey,
brother of Tommy, and only a few
notches below him in national rank.
T Dorsey, the supposed savior of
the much disputed name-band policy
for the board, and a long favorite at
Hopkins affairs, accepted another offer last Saturday, two days before
the Hopkins option expired.
Because of the shortness of time
remaining, the event will in all probability be postponed from next Thursday until February 23.
Beginning their quest for the
name-band dance with hopes of acquiring Larry Clinton and Artie
Shaw, the committee was forced to
give up hopes, when the popular
leaders skyrocketed their prices to
$1750. The committee then swung
its choice to Jan Savitt but switched
to T Dorsey when the option arrived.
Having just completed an arrangePage 4, please

Commission polls
upper classes
Enthusiastic over the recent poll
conducted on freshmen students of
the dormitories in an effort to learn
the students feelings on the Honor
System and its step child, the Slip
System, the Honor Commispion is
laying plans to place the question
before the upper classmen and learn
their reactions on the subject.
The survey conducted at the dormitories indicated that an overwhelming majority of the freshmen favored
the present Honor system, but the
report also indicated that a great
portion of the students are opposed
to the Slip system as a method of enforcing it.
Many of the students who were
questioned averred that they would
not turn in slips under any conditions,
while still others favored other
methods of enforcing the system. A
number of excellent suggestions were
received by the committee, and it is
possible that 'some changes may be
forthcoming in the future. Present
plans call for the upperclass poll to
be conducted within the coming
month.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1939

We are as chagrined as
the rest of those unfortunates who proceeded to make
dates in hasty anticipation
of the highly-touted, much
awaited big - name band
dance debut of the B S A.
Further, we're a little red-faced and guilty-conscienced
about the whole business, feeling a measure of responsibility, insofar as the NEWS-LETTER'S enthusiasm
over the matter manifested itself in pounds of front
page black ink.
And now—No Dorsey!
Where lies the burden of the blame? Shall we
chastise the BSA for dallying too long, and expecting
too much on too short notice? . . . or the Dean for
insisting on 300 guarantees before allowing corltwt?
. . . or us, the students, ourselves, for delaying too
long in signing pledges? We don't know, nor do we
consider it especially important.
We will repeat that we think the BSA sincere anclhardworking in its efforts to supply a rounded social
program at a nominal cost. But we do think the burden too difficult to transport successfully under the
present handicapped set-up.
The requirement of 300 pledges is not an unfair
one,sand yet is one which will prove a boomerang to
the Board repeatedly. The number is high, and requires time to collect. Big name bands are business
organizations which unfortunately associate with themselves such mundane matters as options and contracts.
Time, tide, and options wait for no man. We may well
expect a recurrence of the Dorsey affair.
We call once again then to the Student council's
attention our formula of last issue. Let the class
dues go toward the foundation for a successful, attractively-priced social program. With this basis,
blanket pledges for a social season should be easily
procurable, since prices will have a guaranteed low
level. And likewise, under such a complete plan, the
necessity for class dues as a sinking fund to cope with
financial disaster will be obviated.
A hasty calculation reveals that if only 300 tickets were sold at three dollars per, optionally deductable from caution money, these tickets to cover an
entire social season, used in conjunction with class
dues this money could provide for two big-name
dances and two small ones, with no chance of "going
under". And the more tickets sold (at this or a lower
price) the more functions would this season include.
We can see nothing wrong with the plan. It entails a mere diversion of funds, compulsorily paid that
they may benefit more students to a greater extent. It
eliminates uncertainty on the part of producers and redipients. And it guarantees a successful social program.
To the discretion of the BSA then, might be left
the planning of the program. To the discretion of the
student body—its extent.
Pro tern, we •rest our case. We invite refutation.

Departure
From
Mein Kampf

The enigma that is Hitler
furthered itself a bit more
in our minds this week, by
virtue of the radio and a
two-and-one-half-hour piece
of chip-on-my-shoulder declamation from the German

front.
For the first time since his ascension to Germanic
supremacy six years ago, der fuehrer made a radical
departure from the program so carefully outlined, and
heretofore so carefully adhered to, in the Aryan New

Testament:Mein Kampf. Herein Hitler expressly states
that the downfall of old Germany was due to its imperialistic policy, a failing to be avoided at all costs.
And yet, paradoxically, last Monday the self-same
author demanded a restoration of all of Germany's
pre-war colonies, •as well as a more equal distribution
of colonial riches among have and have-not nations.
Making no mention of either Memel or the Ukraine,
and merely cautioning a friendly neutrality on the
part of Poland, Czechoslovakia, and neighboring states,
the address turned its focus from the continent abroad.
Despite the recognition, finally, of the fact that
"Germany is and has been in a particularly trying economic situation", and must fact the ever-present problems of lack of raw materials, over-population, and
shortage of trade, we cannot see Hitler envisioning a
return of Germany's colonies as his solution. The figures bear out the facts. Of the six basic raw materials:
iron, coal, copper, rubber, oil, cotton, these lands had
and still have none to speak of. Southwest Africa's trifling percentage of copper production has itself now
ceased.
In consideration of trade or population importance
the figures are just as significant. Prior to 1914 only
20,000 Germans had emigrated to colonies. True, there
was no Hitler to enforce such action, but again, enforced colonization is rarely if ever successful. Of a
total world trade of 40 billion dollars, these colonies
were only participating to the extent of less than 800
million. And Hitler's own argument—"The pretext
that these colonial possessions are of no value should
justify their return"—shows his recognition of these
salient points.
That the Rome-Berlin axis is the answer we realize.
But we cannot believe that it is the answer from the
point of view which Hitler seemed so anxious to impress. True, the Reich owes Italy a debt. True, also,
that Italy as a colony grabber seems to make Hitler's
offer of alliance, in case of any attack on her, valid.
However, we cannot escape the conviction that Adolf
is not quite the knight in shining armor he would have
the world believe. Far more important to him, we believe is assurance of Italian alliance When he stops
his silly colony chatter and returns tq the drang nach
osten. And so we are forced to regard the address as
a defensive rather than an aggressive instrument, one
designed to buy Italian good will at all costs.
The House of Common's in England, however,
heard an interesting bit of comment a few weeks ago
when the Secretary of Colonies said there was no section of opinion in England favoring a return of the
colonies to Germany. Yet we read that Mr. Chamberlain regards the address as a peaceful sign.
When the cauldron ceases boiling, the brew will be
strange.
Student interest should
run high . concerning the
proceedings at the Council
meeting this afternoon. The
hospitalization plan coming
up for discussion will air
the grievances of those many
who have bewailed the present scheme as offering
nothing new to the general student body, while requiring the payment of a compulsory fee.
Considered as a whole, the student body does not
object to a medical fee-, provided that a complete service, the benefits of which shall naturally accrue to
them, is offered. Such an attitude is wholly understandable. The pressing need at the time to the minds of
most, as well as to our own, is for some type of infirmary. The request is not an unreasonable one. It is,
likewise, not too great.
A workable plan, feasible from the viewpoints of
both administration and students should not be too
difficult of evolution., We hope to see such a plan introduced and effected by the Council.

It is gratifying to note that in this material, hard
world of today, the finer things are still cherished to
the extent that a multitude notices and mourns the
passing of one who has contributed much to the lightening of men's heavy hearts.
Poet, author, essayist, playwright, biographer—
he made his touch felt wherever the pen could reach.
A follower of Standish O'Grady, he helped initiate the
Irish Literary revival Unafraid of his convictions,
he did not hesitate to face sharp criticism in decrying
the Irish Nationalist school.
William Butler Yeats, of status unquestioned,
passed away this week. We beg the right to add our
little tribute to the rest.

Mr Reuben Baer, gym instructor,
launches his intramural non-fraternity
athletic schedule Tuesday, Feb 7 at
4 pm when two basketball games will
be played by the engineeits. The AB
teams will play Friday of the same
week.

Making
next
negotiations for
years basketball games, Dr Wilson
Schaffer, director of athletics, announced this week that a letter had
been sent to Princeton University
requesting that Hopkins be placed on
their basketball schedule for 1939.

The program consist of three
sports; touch football in the fall,
basketball in the winter, and softball in the spring. There will be round
tournaments in each of these sports.
Each league will consist of four teams
and the present basketball league
will be a three game league.

The letter was sent last week and
a reply is not expected until the
Princeton authorities have completed
next year's Ivy League schedule.
Princeton, which has relations with
Hopkins only in lacrosse, competes
in the Ivy League with teams such
as Yale, Harvard, Columbia, Cornell,
and Penn. According to Mr Mallonee,
however, the Blue Jay squad should
not encounter a very strong basketball team at Princeton.

These teams will meet through out
this year and the following years the
students are in the university. The
purpose is to get as many non-fraternity men as possible interested in
intramural sports, and especially to
keep these fellows active in the
sports. Several teams which were
organized last year and the year before are still playing together this
year, and these teams are slated to
take part in the league. The Literati
team is an example of one of these
teams which was organized as freshmen.

Tossers face Towson teachers
in revenge battle Tuesday night'
Their -victory appetite whetted by their early season loss to Hopkins
last month, the Towson State Teachers college basketball squad is anticipating to turn the tables when the natural rivals meet again next Tuesday
night at Towson.
Hopkins, in the second game of the season, defeated the Towsonites
by a score of 52 to 29 at Homewood. Leading the Blue Jay squad were
Captain Melvin and Bud Tannenbaum with 15 and 14 points respectively.

Gymboree night
plans announced
A fast moving program of sports
and other campus activities has been
arranged for Gymboree night to be
held at Homewood sometime in
March, it was announced this week
by Mr Reuben Baer, director.
Although the entire affair is tentative, the event will probably be held
on March 8.
Instituted by Mr Baer four years
ago as a means of providing an interesting evening for the student
body and also to provide an outlet
for the interfraternal and intramural
sports, Gymboree night has enjoyed
a great success.
Heading the program will be the
finals of the fraternity basket ball
league. Last year, in a fight for the
Turbyville trophy, TA conquered
Kappa Sig by a score of 26 to 22, in
an uphill fight.
The fraternities, divided into three
leagues, are now conducting a roundrobin tournament to determine the
most superior in each league. Previous to the affair, Mr Baer will
choose What he considers the weakest
of the three teams and match it
against the strongest. In this manner, the director hopes to find the
strongest teams and present them
before the Gymboree night crowd.
Hopkins' Greek gladiators will pit
their pulling strength against each
other when the fraternities stage the
popular tug-of-war.
The program will be completed with
exhibitions of tumbling and fencing.
Mr Baer expects some freshmen to
participate in pyramid building.

Packed Latrobe hall
hears Archibald MacLeish
give last of poetry lectures
"Prose is prose whether it is art or
not," Archibald MacLeish said in his
fifth lecture on poetry, "poetry ceases
to be poetry when it is not art."
Talking with a fever of 102, he
continued in a clarification of the
nature of poetry.
"Art in America is too frequently
confused with exoticism. Art was the
assignment of culture for a nation
of Empire builders which had no art,
but collected it for snobbish reasons
and because it added respectability.
The artist is a figure of the most
banal reality. The end of poetry is to
create with words a real image other
than their own: first an image on the
surface of sounds and accents and
second, an arrangement of images
and concepts on the sub-surface.
"It is on the sub-surface that poetry does its work", he said. "The ink
of poetry is invisible ink. It is this
that makes poetry real."
He illustrated the broadness of subject matter for the poet, emphasizing
a minimum threshold of emotion,
with readings from Gerald Hopkins
and the recent William Butler Yeats.

Over eight hundred return to a
hum-drum - - what a conundrum
By KENNETH MAXCY JR
The intensive "back-to-class"
movement sponsored by the NEWSLETTER yesterday and today has succeeded in returning over eight hundred students to their classes, according to a flash from the registrar.
The promising results have led the
NEWS-LETTER to consider a campuswide poll on—College, yes? or no?
Comments on the exams show
unfavorable
universal
practically
sentiment on the lack of imagination
in exam questions. Disapproving students even went so far as to greet
some examinations with stamping
feet and cat-calls.
"These questions have less personality than the questions in a teacher's text supplement," one student
was overheard to say. Such a scathing indictment reflects to a large extent upon the faculty.
The official notice that "ignorance
is no excuse" also received pointed
criticism.
Compliments were received by the
administration, however, on the firstaid stations and refreshment stands
installed betwen examination rooms.
This rebuked the Student council
which had objected to them as
against the "democratic" school
spirit of "rugged individualism."
The mysterious sudden appearance
of swarms of butterflies in the History B examination room is still unexplained. Conjectures relating it to
the high price of spinach have been
generally discredited by a subsequent
fall in the price of spinach and the

continued appearance of the swarms
of butterflies.
And now that we can pick up the
poker hands where we left off and
finish off that stein of malt, we have
started looking around for a shady
spot to sit and watch the spring grass
grow until finals.
So, in a reasonably accurate facsimile of words by the imortal 0'
Henry let us conclude. "Oh! heap our
plates with golden fruit and let us
twine round our brows wreathes of
poison ivy, for the season of irresponsibility is at hand."

York State.

Band adopts ROTC
rank system
"In an effort to build up spirit in
the band in the hope of adding spirit
to the campus, the band has instigated a system of rank copied after
that used in the regular ROTC units.
The band, mainly a school and not
an ROTC function, has not, in the
past, been very well coordinated.
There was a definite lack of incentive,
the varsity seal being the only reward for membership, and attendance
at games and drills was very poor.
The creation of three sergeants
was the first step to increase band
spirit and a set of awards is being
worked out in this connection.
The three sergeants appointed are
Bill Wetzler, George Elliot, and
Francis Diehl.
Since these appointments few
weeks ago, there has been a definite
improvement in band spirit and
morale as represented by better drill
attendance and increased cooperation.
It is hoped that this improvement
will be continued in order that the
organization be able to gain the recognition it should receive on the
campus. The structure and material
are present to give Hopkins a real
band, and under these new adjustments, this hope may be realized.

meets officially
next Friday
The first official meeting of the
Liberal Club will be held next Friday
at 1:00 in Levering hall, it was decided

at an organization meeting
yesterday. Two members of the faculty will speak on the purpose of the
club and their interpretation of a
liberal. The meeting will be an open
one, with the entire student body invited. Murray Kempton will outline
for newcomers the proposed structure
and functions of the group.

coming meeting. Next Thursday at
lunch time the club organizers will
meet in the NEWS-LETTER office to delimit the fields covered by each of

this opportunity to welcome bailt

Dorsey refusing an offer by the
Board of Social Activities this week,
sent the committee scurrying again
for a name band with a great Baltimore following, and upset all planned
arrangements for the affair scheduled for February 9, at the Alcazar.

after more than three hundred pledges

caused an important meeting between Harold Ricards, president of
the Student council and the BSA
this afternoon.

for the board, and a long favorite at

the Hopkins option expired.
Because of the shortness of time
remaining, the event will in all probability be postponed from next Thursday until February 23.
Beginning their quest for the

Shaw, the committee was forced to
give up hopes, when the popular
leaders skyrocketed their prices to
$1750. The committee then swung
its choice to Jan Savitt but switched
to T Dorsey when the option arrived.

Enthusiastic over the recent poll
conducted on freshmen students of
the dormitories in an effort to learn
the students feelings on the Honor
System and its step child, the Slip
System, the Honor Commispion is
laying plans to place the question
before the upper classmen and learn
their reactions on the subject.
The survey conducted at the dormitories indicated that an overwhelming majority of the freshmen favored
the present Honor system, but the
report also indicated that a great
portion of the students are opposed
to the Slip system as a method of enforcing it.
Many of the students who were
questioned averred that they would
not turn in slips under any conditions,
while still others favored other
methods of enforcing the system. A
number of excellent suggestions were
received by the committee, and it is
possible that 'some changes may be
forthcoming in the future. Present
plans call for the upperclass poll to
be conducted within the coming
month.

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1939

We are as chagrined as
the rest of those unfortunates who proceeded to make
dates in hasty anticipation
of the highly-touted, much
awaited big - name band
dance debut of the B S A.
Further, we're a little red-faced and guilty-conscienced
about the whole business, feeling a measure of responsibility, insofar as the NEWS-LETTER'S enthusiasm
over the matter manifested itself in pounds of front
page black ink.
And now—No Dorsey!
Where lies the burden of the blame? Shall we
chastise the BSA for dallying too long, and expecting
too much on too short notice? . . . or the Dean for
insisting on 300 guarantees before allowing corltwt?
. . . or us, the students, ourselves, for delaying too
long in signing pledges? We don't know, nor do we
consider it especially important.
We will repeat that we think the BSA sincere anclhardworking in its efforts to supply a rounded social
program at a nominal cost. But we do think the burden too difficult to transport successfully under the
present handicapped set-up.
The requirement of 300 pledges is not an unfair
one,sand yet is one which will prove a boomerang to
the Board repeatedly. The number is high, and requires time to collect. Big name bands are business
organizations which unfortunately associate with themselves such mundane matters as options and contracts.
Time, tide, and options wait for no man. We may well
expect a recurrence of the Dorsey affair.
We call once again then to the Student council's
attention our formula of last issue. Let the class
dues go toward the foundation for a successful, attractively-priced social program. With this basis,
blanket pledges for a social season should be easily
procurable, since prices will have a guaranteed low
level. And likewise, under such a complete plan, the
necessity for class dues as a sinking fund to cope with
financial disaster will be obviated.
A hasty calculation reveals that if only 300 tickets were sold at three dollars per, optionally deductable from caution money, these tickets to cover an
entire social season, used in conjunction with class
dues this money could provide for two big-name
dances and two small ones, with no chance of "going
under". And the more tickets sold (at this or a lower
price) the more functions would this season include.
We can see nothing wrong with the plan. It entails a mere diversion of funds, compulsorily paid that
they may benefit more students to a greater extent. It
eliminates uncertainty on the part of producers and redipients. And it guarantees a successful social program.
To the discretion of the BSA then, might be left
the planning of the program. To the discretion of the
student body—its extent.
Pro tern, we •rest our case. We invite refutation.

Departure
From
Mein Kampf

The enigma that is Hitler
furthered itself a bit more
in our minds this week, by
virtue of the radio and a
two-and-one-half-hour piece
of chip-on-my-shoulder declamation from the German

front.
For the first time since his ascension to Germanic
supremacy six years ago, der fuehrer made a radical
departure from the program so carefully outlined, and
heretofore so carefully adhered to, in the Aryan New

Testament:Mein Kampf. Herein Hitler expressly states
that the downfall of old Germany was due to its imperialistic policy, a failing to be avoided at all costs.
And yet, paradoxically, last Monday the self-same
author demanded a restoration of all of Germany's
pre-war colonies, •as well as a more equal distribution
of colonial riches among have and have-not nations.
Making no mention of either Memel or the Ukraine,
and merely cautioning a friendly neutrality on the
part of Poland, Czechoslovakia, and neighboring states,
the address turned its focus from the continent abroad.
Despite the recognition, finally, of the fact that
"Germany is and has been in a particularly trying economic situation", and must fact the ever-present problems of lack of raw materials, over-population, and
shortage of trade, we cannot see Hitler envisioning a
return of Germany's colonies as his solution. The figures bear out the facts. Of the six basic raw materials:
iron, coal, copper, rubber, oil, cotton, these lands had
and still have none to speak of. Southwest Africa's trifling percentage of copper production has itself now
ceased.
In consideration of trade or population importance
the figures are just as significant. Prior to 1914 only
20,000 Germans had emigrated to colonies. True, there
was no Hitler to enforce such action, but again, enforced colonization is rarely if ever successful. Of a
total world trade of 40 billion dollars, these colonies
were only participating to the extent of less than 800
million. And Hitler's own argument—"The pretext
that these colonial possessions are of no value should
justify their return"—shows his recognition of these
salient points.
That the Rome-Berlin axis is the answer we realize.
But we cannot believe that it is the answer from the
point of view which Hitler seemed so anxious to impress. True, the Reich owes Italy a debt. True, also,
that Italy as a colony grabber seems to make Hitler's
offer of alliance, in case of any attack on her, valid.
However, we cannot escape the conviction that Adolf
is not quite the knight in shining armor he would have
the world believe. Far more important to him, we believe is assurance of Italian alliance When he stops
his silly colony chatter and returns tq the drang nach
osten. And so we are forced to regard the address as
a defensive rather than an aggressive instrument, one
designed to buy Italian good will at all costs.
The House of Common's in England, however,
heard an interesting bit of comment a few weeks ago
when the Secretary of Colonies said there was no section of opinion in England favoring a return of the
colonies to Germany. Yet we read that Mr. Chamberlain regards the address as a peaceful sign.
When the cauldron ceases boiling, the brew will be
strange.
Student interest should
run high . concerning the
proceedings at the Council
meeting this afternoon. The
hospitalization plan coming
up for discussion will air
the grievances of those many
who have bewailed the present scheme as offering
nothing new to the general student body, while requiring the payment of a compulsory fee.
Considered as a whole, the student body does not
object to a medical fee-, provided that a complete service, the benefits of which shall naturally accrue to
them, is offered. Such an attitude is wholly understandable. The pressing need at the time to the minds of
most, as well as to our own, is for some type of infirmary. The request is not an unreasonable one. It is,
likewise, not too great.
A workable plan, feasible from the viewpoints of
both administration and students should not be too
difficult of evolution., We hope to see such a plan introduced and effected by the Council.

"THE STORM IS IN MY HAIR AND I MUST GO"
It is gratifying to note that in this material, hard
world of today, the finer things are still cherished to
the extent that a multitude notices and mourns the
passing of one who has contributed much to the lightening of men's heavy hearts.
Poet, author, essayist, playwright, biographer—
he made his touch felt wherever the pen could reach.
A follower of Standish O'Grady, he helped initiate the
Irish Literary revival Unafraid of his convictions,
he did not hesitate to face sharp criticism in decrying
the Irish Nationalist school.
William Butler Yeats, of status unquestioned,
passed away this week. We beg the right to add our
little tribute to the rest.

Cage tilt

Mr Reuben Baer, gym instructor,
launches his intramural non-fraternity
athletic schedule Tuesday, Feb 7 at
4 pm when two basketball games will
be played by the engineeits. The AB
teams will play Friday of the same
week.

Making
next
negotiations for
years basketball games, Dr Wilson
Schaffer, director of athletics, announced this week that a letter had
been sent to Princeton University
requesting that Hopkins be placed on
their basketball schedule for 1939.

The program consist of three
sports; touch football in the fall,
basketball in the winter, and softball in the spring. There will be round
tournaments in each of these sports.
Each league will consist of four teams
and the present basketball league
will be a three game league.

The letter was sent last week and
a reply is not expected until the
Princeton authorities have completed
next year's Ivy League schedule.
Princeton, which has relations with
Hopkins only in lacrosse, competes
in the Ivy League with teams such
as Yale, Harvard, Columbia, Cornell,
and Penn. According to Mr Mallonee,
however, the Blue Jay squad should
not encounter a very strong basketball team at Princeton.

These teams will meet through out
this year and the following years the
students are in the university. The
purpose is to get as many non-fraternity men as possible interested in
intramural sports, and especially to
keep these fellows active in the
sports. Several teams which were
organized last year and the year before are still playing together this
year, and these teams are slated to
take part in the league. The Literati
team is an example of one of these
teams which was organized as freshmen.
The first A B team, which will
play on Friday is as follows:

Fisher, Blum, Steinbach, Kurland,
Liepman, Schapiro, Rudo.

Jayvees to meet
St Paul Wednesday
COACH MCNALLY'S undefeated jayvee basketball squad is practicing
diligently in the gym preparing for
the coming scrap with St Paul prep
school next Wednesday afternoon in
the latters gym.

Aggressive and smooth, the big St
Paul team should be able to put up
a stiff fight, and may mar the perfect record of the home team.
Led by Moxley, the pivot man, and
Galloway, a good shot from all parts
of the floor, the prep school squad has
been able to lead the Maryland Scholastic B Conference cage league with
three wins and no defeats.
The opposing five is rounded out
by Colman, lanky center, Norman and
Smedley, forwards.
Undecided in several positions until he has seen his charges in action,
Coach McNally held extensive practice to determine his starting lineup.
The freshmen team, also coached
by McNally, will resume their playing schedule next Friday, when they
tangle Friend's school at Homewood.

Gwinn calls
for runners
Beginning three weeks of intensive
practive in preparation for the first
meet, Coach Dick Gwinn issued a
call for candidates in all distances.
Hopkins will open the season on
March 4, when they run in the Catholic university games in Washington.
On March 11, the Blue Jay team
will enter the Mason-Dixon relay in
the University of Maryland-Fifth
Regiment Armory games. Although
they have had only a few practice
sessions, Coach Gwinn announced
that the team will probably be formed
from "Otts" Langford, Pestrunt,
Rosner, and Driscoll. The relay consists of a 220 yard match, two onequarter mile races, and ends with a
half-mile run.

Dr Schaffer also announced that a
letter had been sent to Army authorities to r en e w basketball relations, which have been severed for the first time in several years

next year.
Hopkins has been anxious to arrange a court series with Princeton
for some time, and Dr Schaffer put
new vigor in his efforts when it was
announced that the New Jersey
school would have an open date next
year.
St John's Place Empty
According to the rules of the Maryland Collegiate League, Hopkins is
slated to meet Mount St Mary's and
Washington College, the two strongest quints in the conference, twice
next year.
The league authorities have not as
yet found a Maryland team to take
St Johns' place, but Towson Teachers,
University of Baltimore, and Blue
Ridge college are under consideration.
With the announcement of the
partial basketball schedule, came the
report that during the halves of the
Haverford and Swarthmore football
games to be held next year on October 28 and November 17, the cross
country team will hold a meet with
the respective schools.

Hopkins takes fourth place
in Maryland Collegiate League

Tossers face Towson teachers
in revenge battle Tuesday night'
Their -victory appetite whetted by their early season loss to Hopkins
last month, the Towson State Teachers college basketball squad is anticipating to turn the tables when the natural rivals meet again next Tuesday
night at Towson.
Hopkins, in the second game of the season, defeated the Towsonites
by a score of 52 to 29 at Homewood. Leading the Blue Jay squad were
Captain Melvin and Bud Tannenbaum with 15 and 14 points respectively.

Gymboree night
plans announced
A fast moving program of sports
and other campus activities has been
arranged for Gymboree night to be
held at Homewood sometime in
March, it was announced this week
by Mr Reuben Baer, director.
Although the entire affair is tentative, the event will probably be held
on March 8.
Instituted by Mr Baer four years
ago as a means of providing an interesting evening for the student
body and also to provide an outlet
for the interfraternal and intramural
sports, Gymboree night has enjoyed
a great success.
Heading the program will be the
finals of the fraternity basket ball
league. Last year, in a fight for the
Turbyville trophy, TA conquered
Kappa Sig by a score of 26 to 22, in
an uphill fight.
The fraternities, divided into three
leagues, are now conducting a roundrobin tournament to determine the
most superior in each league. Previous to the affair, Mr Baer will
choose What he considers the weakest
of the three teams and match it
against the strongest. In this manner, the director hopes to find the
strongest teams and present them
before the Gymboree night crowd.
Hopkins' Greek gladiators will pit
their pulling strength against each
other when the fraternities stage the
popular tug-of-war.
The program will be completed with
exhibitions of tumbling and fencing.
Mr Baer expects some freshmen to
participate in pyramid building.

Packed Latrobe hall
hears Archibald MacLeish
give last of poetry lectures
"Prose is prose whether it is art or
not," Archibald MacLeish said in his
fifth lecture on poetry, "poetry ceases
to be poetry when it is not art."
Talking with a fever of 102, he
continued in a clarification of the
nature of poetry.
"Art in America is too frequently
confused with exoticism. Art was the
assignment of culture for a nation
of Empire builders which had no art,
but collected it for snobbish reasons
and because it added respectability.
The artist is a figure of the most
banal reality. The end of poetry is to
create with words a real image other
than their own: first an image on the
surface of sounds and accents and
second, an arrangement of images
and concepts on the sub-surface.
"It is on the sub-surface that poetry does its work", he said. "The ink
of poetry is invisible ink. It is this
that makes poetry real."
He illustrated the broadness of subject matter for the poet, emphasizing
a minimum threshold of emotion,
with readings from Gerald Hopkins
and the recent William Butler Yeats.

"The purpose of the organization
is to place emphasis upon investigation." (I quote last week's NewsLetter) Such a purpose should be
innocuous enough to attract men of
curiosity but hardly men of action,"
This effort has come as the last
desperate stand of a handful of dissenters within the ASU, who differ
with the overwhelming majority of
members in the 200 college and high
school ASU chapters, members who
have proved by consistent actions as
well as words that they are truly
"liberals" in the best sense of the
word.
The ASU is recognized by many
college heads and public figures as
the authoritative spokesman for progressive student thought. It has
justly earned this position through
its continuing efforts to stimulate the
spirit of
progressive democracy
throughout college life and beyond
that in it effect on students' thinking.
To be sure organizations, like humans, have their faults, and to this
the ASU is no exception At Hopkins,
many organizational weaknesses have
delayed its reaching the heights it
has attained at Harvard, for example,
where the ASU has 400 members or
at Swarthmore with 300 members.
The Hopkins Student union has
strength and influence none-the-less
and gave good evidence of it in such
battles for student democracy as the
Shils. case of 2 years ago.
It's important therefore that students know the true facts as they
exist so that they may choose with
intelligence and not be bewildered by
a mass of confusing and meaningless
pleas for suport. The ASU has proved
itself to be the place for true liberals
